column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=With each internal reflection the angle which a light ray makes with the longitudinal axis of core 30 decreases by 2.beta..
#Text=Thus, the angle which ray 60 of FIG. 3 makes with the longitudinal axis of core 30 is 2.beta. less than the angle which ray 58 makes therewith.
#Text=As shown in FIG. 4, a ray 62 entering the edge of endface 36 at angle .theta..sub.c will result in a refracted ray 64 which undergoes the maximum number of reflections.

#Text=The finally reflected ray 66 makes an angle with respect to the longitudinal axis of core 30 that is 2M.beta. less than the angle which ray 64 made therewith, where M is the total number of reflections.
#Text=The output angle .chi. is related to the input angle .theta. by the refractive indices of the light source, core, and optical waveguide as well as the total number of reflections.
#Text=The figures depicting the various embodiments are not drawn to scale but are shown in such a manner as to illustrate the present invention.
#Text=For example, the core taper need not be perfectly linear as illustrated.

#Text=However, couplers having substantially linearly tapering cores can be obtained by heating a large diameter fiber and drawing the same in accordance with techniques well known in the fiber optic fabrication art.
#Text=By controlling the temperature and the pulling force, the desired taper angle can be achieved.
#Text=Moreover, the thickness of the cladding layer need not be constant, and probably will not be perfectly constant if the light coupler is made by the aforementioned drawing process.
#Text=The thickness of the cladding layer should be great enough to prevent any significant amount of evanescent energy from reaching the outer surface thereof.

#Text=This minimum cladding thickness is determined by the refractive indices of the transparent core and cladding materials and is usually no less than about 10 times the wavelength of light propagation through the device.
#Text=In the above described embodiment the light coupler core consists of a homogeneous element, the refractive index of which is constant throughout its length.
#Text=However, each end of core 30 of FIG. 2 has its own refractive index requirements.

#Text=The refractive index of core 30 in the vicinity of endface 36 should be as high as possible so that light rays which enter endface 36 and are incident upon interface 34 at small angles with respect to the normal thereto are reflected from that interface.

#Text=The refractive index of that portion of core 30 at endface 38 should be similar to that of the core material in the light transmitting medium to provide maximum coupling efficiency at that interface.
#Text=To illustrate this problem, assume that the light transmitting means is made from doped fused silica and has a refractive index less than 1.5.

#Text=If core 30 had a refractive index of about 1.5 in order to provide good coupling efficiency between coupler 26 and light transmitting means 46, the numerical aperture of the coupler at endface 36 would be relatively low and much of the light incident upon interface 34 near endface 36 would escape from the coupler.
#Text=This problem can be overcome by providing a coupler core having a refractive index which varies either gradually or in a stepped fashion.
#Text=For example, the embodiment of FIG. 2 could utilize a core fabricated by the technique described in U.S.
#Text=Pat. application Ser.
#Text=No. 239,702 entitled "Optical Waveguide Light Source Coupler" filed by F.
#Text=P.
#Text=Kapron and D.
#Text=B.
#Text=Keck on even date herewith, now U.S.
#Text=Pat.

#Text=That application describes a process whereby a boule of doped fused silica is formed by a flame hydrolysis process, the amount of dopant present in the boule being relatively low at one end and gradually increasing toward the other end of the boule.

#Text=Thus, the refractive index of that end of core 30 adjacent to endface 38 could be about 1.46 and the refractive index of the core could gradually increase toward endface 36 where increased dopant concentration could increase the refractive index to about 1.50.
#Text=In the embodiment illustrated in FIG. 5, the coupler core consists of sections 70, 72 and 74, which are named in order of increasing refractive index.
#Text=Cladding layer 76 makes an interface 78 with section 70, an interface 80 with section 72 and an interface 82 with section 74.
#Text=In this embodiment, thin transparent layers 86 and 88 bond coupler 26' to light source 42' and optical waveguide 90, respectively.
#Text=Layers 86 and 88 may consist of epoxy or other suitable transparent bonding material having a refractive index approaching that of the materials disposed adjacent thereto.
#Text=It is preferred that endfaces 36' and 38' be in direct contact with the elements disposed adjacent thereto as shown in FIG. 2.

#Text=If the light source must be spaced from endface 36' such as by the layer of bonding material 86, the refractive index of the bonding material should be as high as possible so that a maximum amount of light is transferred from the source into the coupler.

#Text=Since section 74 has a relatively high refractive index, that end of light coupler 26' adjacent to entrance face 36' has a relatively high numerical aperture and accepts a relatively large portion of the light emitted by source 42'.

#Text=Thus, even those light rays entering endface 36' and being incident upon interface 82 at relatively small angles with respect to the normal thereto are totally internally reflected and propagate toward endface 38'.
#Text=As shown hereinabove, each reflection which a light ray undergoes reduces the angle which the reflected ray makes with the longitudinal axis of the coupler by twice the taper half-angle .beta..

#Text=Therefore, after a ray reflects a number of times from interface 82, it can enter section 72 and reflect from interface 80 even though the refractive index difference between section 72 and cladding layer 76 is less than the refractive index difference between section 74 and cladding layer 76.
#Text=Similarly, the ray enters section 70 making an even smaller angle with respect to the longitudinal axis of the coupler after having undergone a number of reflections within section 72.

#Text=Section 70 can be made from doped fused silica having a refractive index approaching that of the core of waveguide 90, thus providing good coupling efficiency between coupler 26' and optical waveguide 90.
